I.</br>Distinguished Leader of the lyric throng,</br>That whilom sooth'd Britannia's pensive ear</br>With the sweet sounds of sentimental song,</br>Wilt thou, removed now to thy native sphere,</br>Above on starry cope of cloudless light—</br>Wilt thou benignly bend a favouring ear</br>To the weak warblings of an earthly muse,</br>Into whose heart such pleasure exquisite</br>Thy tuneful reliques frequently infuse,</br>That gratitude compels her now to pay</br>Thy memory, charming Bard!  the tribute of a lay?

II.</br>Each kind affection of the heart</br>By thee was intimately known—</br>PITY still prompt assistance to impart,</br>And feel the woes of others as her own:</br>And meek-eyed MERCY, still inclined to spare,</br>When scowling Vengeance rais'd his angry arm</br>To strike, regardless of the victim's prayer,</br>Till sooth'd by her persuasive charm,</br>His rage grows cool — evaporates in air—</br>And drops the lifted blade that threaten'd instant harm.

III.</br>The knowledge of the PASSIONS too was thine—</br>Thy skilful hand could nicely trace</br>Their various features, and combine</br>Them with such sweet poetic grace,</br>That in the glowing line,</br>A strong and striking portraiture of each</br>(So high thy tuneful art could reach!)</br>The wondering senses found.</br>And still as Music touch'd th' appropriate string,</br>Obedient to the potent sound,</br>Alternately they'd fall and rise,</br>And moving in a magic ring,</br>Excite increas'd emotions of surprise.

IV.</br>The MANNERS, too, by Fancy dress'd,</br>In many a wild, cameleon vest,</br>Were to thy keen, observant view</br>Display'd, in every change of hue.</br>Thy nimble pencil caught their flight</br>With the velocity of light,</br>And in unfading tints of nature warm,</br>Fix'd and embodied each fugacious form.

V.</br>The ALLEGORIC train, that rove</br>By Fancy's haunted stream and grove,</br>And fan her mystic flame,</br>Depicted in thy strains we find,</br>Those strains that e'en "the shadowy tribes of mind"</br>Could charm, arrest, and tame.

VI.</br>But when thy verse, "like Sparta's fife,</br>In solemn sounds awakes to life</br>The forms applauding Freedom loved to view,"</br>When it laments the injuries she bore</br>From vandal rage, in days of yore,</br>And bans the barbarous crew;</br>What moving pathos marks the tale</br>Of LIBERTY oppress'd!</br>But see!  once more her struggling arms prevail,</br>And Albion's sons their glorious guardian hail,</br>Great "Mistress of the West."
VI.</br>How sweet thy soothing, doric numbers steal</br>Upon still, pensive EVENING'S listening ear,</br>In softest cadence breath'd,</br>Like her own "dying gale!"

VIII.</br>SIMPLICITY thy tuneful call</br>Rejoicing heard, who gives to all</br>Her gentle train a grace that none beside,</br>Nor rank, nor power, nor art,</br>Nor riches can impart—</br>Sweet nymph!  to spotless Truth and Friendship near allied.

IX.</br>Does Worth, or Genius, to the tomb descend,</br>Snatch'd from the world in an untimely hour—</br>Doth generous Valour to misfortune bend,</br>Or blooming Beauty mourn her blasted flower—</br>In tenderest tones, thy sympathizing shell</br>Teaches the feeling heart with kindred grief to swell.

X.</br>Great Lyrist!  to thy gifted mind</br>The Muse her holiest views unveil'd.</br>Thy skill in all her mystic lore,</br>On every leaf impress'd we find,</br>Of that delightful fairy field,</br>Thy plastic pen has left behind,</br>For Britain's future Minstrels to explore.

XI.</br>Though Criticism, of aspect sour,</br>Jealous of thy superior power</br>To soar beyond his limited control,</br>May keenly search to find some flaw,</br>Some breach of the despotic law</br>He frames to cramp the sallies of the soul—</br>Yet long as genius, sentiment and fire,</br>The life and ornament of verse remain,</br>The fine effusions of thy lofty lyre</br>Shall never cease to charm true Taste's distinguish'd train.</br>
